      • hasAccount

        public boolean hasAccount(javax.servlet.ServletRequest request)
        Description copied from interface: AccountResolver
        Returns true if the specified request has an associated user account identity, false otherwise. Often used as a guard/check before executing AccountResolver.getRequiredAccount(javax.servlet.ServletRequest).
        Specified by:
        hasAccount in interface AccountResolver
        Parameters:
        request - the current servlet request.
        Returns:
        true if the specified request has an associated user account identity, false otherwise.
        See Also:
        AccountResolver.getRequiredAccount(javax.servlet.ServletRequest)

      • findAccount

        protected Account findAccount(javax.servlet.ServletRequest request)

      • getAccount

        public Account getAccount(javax.servlet.ServletRequest request)
        Description copied from interface: AccountResolver
        Returns the current user account associated with the specified request or null if no user account is associated with the request.

        In security-sensitive workflows, it might be better to use AccountResolver.getRequiredAccount(javax.servlet.ServletRequest) to help eliminate NullPointerExceptions and conditional branching bugs.

        Specified by:
        getAccount in interface AccountResolver
        Parameters:
        request - the current servlet request.
        Returns:
        the current user account associated with the specified request or null if no user account is associated with the request.
        See Also:
        AccountResolver.hasAccount(javax.servlet.ServletRequest), AccountResolver.getRequiredAccount(javax.servlet.ServletRequest)

      • getRequiredAccount

        public Account getRequiredAccount(javax.servlet.ServletRequest request)
        Description copied from interface: AccountResolver
        Returns the current user account identity associated with the request or throws an IllegalArgumentException exception if there is no account associated with the request.

        Often this method will be used within a conditional, first checking that AccountResolver.hasAccount(javax.servlet.ServletRequest) returns true, for example:

             if (AccountResolver.INSTANCE.hasAccount(servletRequest)) {

         Account account = AccountResolver.INSTANCE.getRequiredAccount(servletRequest);
         //do something with the account

     }
        This check-then-use pattern helps eliminate NullPointerExceptions and conditional branching bugs when working with user identities - often desirable in sensitive logic.
        Specified by:
        getRequiredAccount in interface AccountResolver
        Parameters:
        request - the current servlet request.
        Returns:
        the current user account identity associated with the request
